babelNetEntity.description: The Lord of the Rings is an epic high fantasy novel written by English author and scholar J. R. R. Tolkien.

Allen & Unwin is an Australian independent publishing company, established in Australia in 1976 as a subsidiary of the British firm George Allen & Unwin Ltd., which was founded by Sir Stanley Unwin in August 1914 and went on to become one of the leading publishers of the twentieth century.
Literary genre
Fantasy is a genre of fiction set in a fictional universe, often without any locations, events, or people referencing the real world.
An extended fictional work in prose; usually in the form of a story
An Indo-European language belonging to the West Germanic branch; the official language of Britain and the United States and most of the commonwealth countries
Peregrin Took, more commonly known simply as Pippin, is a fictional character from J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy novel The Lord of the Rings.
Boromir is a fictional character in J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium.
In J. R. R. Tolkien's Middle-earth legendarium, Faramir is a fictional character appearing in The Lord of the Rings.
Meriadoc Brandybuck, usually referred to as simply Merry, is a fictional character from J. R. R. Tolkien's Middle-earth legendarium, featured throughout his most famous work, The Lord of the Rings.
Gandalf is a fictional character and one of the protagonists in J. R. R. Tolkien's novels The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.
Gimli is a fictional character from J. R. R. Tolkien's Middle-earth legendarium, featured in The Lord of the Rings.
Samwise "Sam" Gamgee is a fictional character in J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium.
Galadriel is a fictional character created by J.R.R. Tolkien, appearing in his Middle-earth legendarium.
Frodo Baggins is a fictional character in J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium, and one of the main protagonists of The Lord of the Rings.
Legolas is a fictional character in J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium.
Bilbo Baggins is the title character and protagonist of J. R. R. Tolkien's 1937 novel The Hobbit, as well as a supporting character in The Lord of the Rings.
Elrond Half-elven is a fictional character in J. R. R. Tolkien's Middle-earth legendarium.
Saruman the White is a fictional character and a major antagonist in J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy novel The Lord of the Rings.
Aragorn II, son of Arathorn is a fictional character from J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium.
British philologist and writer of fantasies (born in South Africa) (1892-1973)
Tolkien's legendarium is the body of J. R. R. Tolkien's mythopoetic writing that forms the background to his The Lord of the Rings.
A literary genre is a category of literary composition.
Harry Potter is a series of fantasy novels written by British author J. K. Rowling.
Publisher
Bloomsbury Publishing plc is a British independent, worldwide publishing house of fiction and non-fiction.

Scholastic Corporation is an American multinational publishing, education and media company known for publishing, selling, and distributing books and educational materials for schools, teachers, parents, and children.
Literary genre
L.E.J, short for Lucie, Élisa and Juliette, sometimes Elijay, is a French band composed of three young women from Saint Denis, a city in Paris' suburbs.
Literary genre
British English is the English language as spoken and written in the United Kingdom.
Fictional character of the Harry Potter series
Fictional character in the Harry Potter universe
Severus Snape is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Character in the Harry Potter franchise
Hermione Jean Granger is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Ronald Bilius "Ron" Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Lord Voldemort is a fictional character and the main antagonist in J. K. Rowling's series of Harry Potter novels.
Harry James Potter is the title character and protagonist of J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Professor Albus Percival Wulfric Brian Dumbledore is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Joanne Rowling,, writing under the pen names J. K. Rowling and Robert Galbraith, is a British novelist, screenwriter, and producer who is best known for writing the Harry Potter fantasy series.
The fictional universe of British author J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series of fantasy novels comprises two distinct societies: the Wizarding World and the Muggle world.
A literary genre is a category of literary composition.
